name: 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonyl azide
Reason: 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonyl azide has a melting point that we can compare to by analyzing its structural components. The basic unit for this compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a sulfonyl group, which can increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The sulfonyl group can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which can further lower the melting point. Additionally, the acetamide group can contribute to the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and increase molecular weight. The azide group can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which can further lower the melting point. The presence of a methoxy group can also increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces.
